elements.content: Flame-retardant (FR) additives are commonly used to improve the fire safety of synthetic polymers, which are widely employed in manufactured consumer goods. Incorporation of an FR in a polymer typically leads to deterioration of its mechanical properties. It also manifests itself in non-negligible volatile organic compound (VOC) release, which in turn increases environmental risks carried by both the application and disposal of the corresponding consumer goods. Herein, we present a hierarchical strategy for the design of composite materials, which ensures simultaneous improvement of both mechanical and fire-safety properties of polymers while limiting the VOC release. Our strategy employs porous metal–organic framework (MOF) particles to provide a multifunctional interface between the FR molecules and the polymer. Specifically, we demonstrate that the particles of environmentally friendly HKUST-1 MOF can be infused by a modern FRdimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP)and then embedded into widely used unsaturated polyesters. The DMMP–HKUST-1 additive endows the resulting composite material with improved processability, flame retardancy, and mechanical properties. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and computational modeling of the additive suggest the complete pore filling of HKUST-1 with DMMP molecules being bound to the open metal sites of the MOF.

elements.content: Synthetic polymers are indispensable to the modern world. They constitute key components of omnipresent manufactured consumer goods. Although widespread in their applications, the suitability of a particular synthetic polymer to a specific product or application is determined by its mechanical, chemical, and physical properties, for example, stiffness and flammability. Many of these properties can be tuned by incorporation of additives. In particular, polymers’ additives that improve their flame retardancy and mechanical properties without increasing health and environmental risks are in high demand. In recent years, phosphorus-containing molecular flame retardants (FRs) have gained importance while replacing their chlorine- or bromine-substituted predecessors. Nevertheless, the development of fire-safe polymers by incorporation of FR additives still poses a significant challenge. First, high dosages of the FR additives are often required to achieve the desired fire-safety levels, at which the deterioration of thermal stability and mechanical properties of the corresponding composites is commonly observed. Second, the FR molecules are not sufficiently immobilized in the composite structure, and their migration onto the polymer surface leads to the release of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Synthetic polymers are indispensable to the modern world. They constitute key components of omnipresent manufactured consumer goods. Although widespread in their applications, the suitability of a particular synthetic polymer to a specific product or application is determined by its mechanical, chemical, and physical properties, for example, stiffness and flammability. Many of these properties can be tuned by incorporation of additives. In particular, polymers' additives that improve their flame retardancy and mechanical properties without increasing health and environmental risks are in high demand. In recent years, phosphorus-containing molecular flame retardants (FRs) have gained importance while replacing their chlorine- or bromine-substituted predecessors. Nevertheless, the development of fire-safe polymers by incorporation of FR additives still poses a significant challenge. First, high dosages of the FR additives are often required to achieve the desired fire-safety levels, at which the deterioration of thermal stability and mechanical properties of the corresponding composites is commonly observed. Second, the FR molecules are not sufficiently immobilized in the composite structure, and their migration onto the polymer surface leads to the release of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) particles have been prototyped as polymer additives. The resulting composite materials have been tested in a number of applications exploiting the material porosity, for example, gas separation, nanofiltration, and capture of VOCs, and have been shown to exhibit better performance than those of their individual components. It has been also recognized that MOFs themselves exhibit some flame-retardant properties as the metal centers within their structure can promote char formation during the combustion of the composite. However, the fire-resistant effect of MOFs is limited with respect to molecular FRs, which can also offer more fire suppression mechanism by quenching the combustion reactions and/or forming a nonflammable layer on the burning material. Conveniently, due to their intrinsic porosity, such molecular flame retardants can be incorporated into MOFs as functional guest molecules.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic framework (MOF) particles have been prototyped as polymer additives. The resulting composite materials have been tested in a number of applications exploiting the material porosity, for example, gas separation, nanofiltration, and capture of VOCs, and have been shown to exhibit better performance than those of their individual components. It has been also recognized that MOFs themselves exhibit some flame-retardant properties as the metal centers within their structure can promote char formation during the combustion of the composite. However, the fire-resistant effect of MOFs is limited with respect to molecular FRs, which can also offer more fire suppression mechanism by quenching the combustion reactions and/or forming a nonflammable layer on the burning material. Conveniently, due to their intrinsic porosity, such molecular flame retardants can be incorporated into MOFs as functional guest molecules.

elements.content: Herein, we present the synthesis and characterization of hierarchical FR–MOF-polymer composites, in which FR-loaded MOF additives offer significant improvement of the polymer’s mechanical and flame retardancy properties. Our work involves thermoset unsaturated polyester (UP) as a polymer matrix (), which incorporates MOF particles encapsulating FR. Highly porous and environmentally friendly HKUST-1 (1) is used as the host MOF, functionalized by encapsulating dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP), which is a widely used modern FR. By comparing the thermal stability, fire-resistant behavior, and mechanical properties, it is found that the DMMP-loaded 1 improves both the flame retardancy and mechanical properties of the composites with respect to the guest-free 1 while also offering a good processability and a negligible VOC release. We refer to our approach as hierarchical due to the arrangement of FR in ranks as opposed to a direct molecular dispersion within the polymer, that is, in our approach, DMMP is encapsulated inside MOF particles, and furthermore, due to the presence of open metal sites (OMSs) in HKUST-1, it is further organized into groups of strongly OMS-bound and pore-filling molecules. Our work highlights new opportunities for improving the performance, environmental friendliness, and likely other properties of polymer composites by using the outlined hierarchical design strategies involving porous MOF particles loaded with property-enhancing guest molecules.

elements.clean_text: 1  Encapsulating FR into MOF and UP Composite Preparation

elements.content: The crystal structure of HKUST-1 (1) is characterized by the largest cavity diameter of ca. 13.5 Å and the pore-limiting diameter of ca. 6.75 Å. The approximate kinetic diameter of DMMP, based on typical bond lengths, is around 6 Å. Therefore, DMMP can penetrate the cavities of 1 as guest molecules. In fact, the volume available to the DMMP molecules can be characterized by the probe occupiable volume (POV), which amounts to 0.65 cm3/g, as calculated by our Zeo++ tool, and corresponds to a void fraction of 57%. POV represents the entire volume that can be occupied by a spherical probe of a given radius. It is different (i.e., larger value) from a commonly used accessible volume, which corresponds to the volume available to the center of the spherical probe. Algorithmic details of POV calculation were presented in ref .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Analysis

The crystal structure of HKUST-1 (1) is characterized by the largest cavity diameter of ca. 13.5 Å and the pore-limiting diameter of ca. 6.75 Å. The approximate kinetic diameter of DMMP, based on typical bond lengths, is around 6 Å. Therefore, DMMP can penetrate the cavities of 1 as guest molecules. In fact, the volume available to the DMMP molecules can be characterized by the probe occupiable volume (POV), which amounts to 0.65 cm3/g, as calculated by our Zeo++ tool, and corresponds to a void fraction of 57%. POV represents the entire volume that can be occupied by a spherical probe of a given radius. It is different (i.e., larger value) from a commonly used accessible volume, which corresponds to the volume available to the center of the spherical probe. Algorithmic details of POV calculation were presented in ref .

elements.content: The integrity of the host framework during our experiment is confirmed by identical powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of DMMP-loaded 1 (1·FR), the corresponding UP composite (1·FR 19/UP, the number in the subscript represents the percentage of additives), and as-synthesized 1 (1·guest), indicating that the original structure of the host framework kept integral after the FR loading and the combination with the polymer matrix (Figure S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) sheds light on the encapsulation of DMMP within the pore system. In the case of the mixture of 1 and the free DMMP liquid, the TGA weight loss curve before 100 °C is almost identical to the single DMMP, whereas the weight loss of sample 1·FR goes much slower and lasts steadily even after the boiling point (bp) of DMMP (180 °C). This remarkable difference in TGA curves suggests that the 1·FR sample has DMMP molecules incorporated inside 1’s pores as guest molecules instead of being adsorbed on the particle surface. The observed slower weight loss trend in 1·FR implies the strong delayed-release of DMMP caused by the pore system in 1.
elements.clean_text: The integrity of the host framework during our experiment is confirmed by identical powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of DMMP-loaded 1 (1⋅FR), the corresponding UP composite (1⋅FR 19/UP, the number in the subscript represents the percentage of additives), and as-synthesized 1 (1⋅guest), indicating that the original structure of the host framework kept integral after the FR loading and the combination with the polymer matrix (Figure S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) sheds light on the encapsulation of DMMP within the pore system. In the case of the mixture of 1 and the free DMMP liquid, the TGA weight loss curve before 100 °C is almost identical to the single DMMP, whereas the weight loss of sample 1⋅FR goes much slower and lasts steadily even after the boiling point (bp) of DMMP (180 °C). This remarkable difference in TGA curves suggests that the 1⋅FR sample has DMMP molecules incorporated inside 1's pores as guest molecules instead of being adsorbed on the particle surface. The observed slower weight loss trend in 1⋅FR implies the strong delayed-release of DMMP caused by the pore system in 1.

elements.content: To determine the encapsulation amount of DMMP, the mass change of powder of 1 before and after loading DMMP was recorded, which resulted in an encapsulation amount of ca. 41 wt % (Table S1). This value corresponds well with an estimate based on POV and the DMMP liquid density of 1150.7 g/cm3 at T = 303 K, which would lead to loading of 42.7 wt % (assuming a crystal density of 0.879 g/cm3). To study the effects of the DMMP confinement inside 1’s pores that could affect the DMMP liquid density in the above calculations, we used grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations to predict the DMMP loading at T = 303 K and a pressure of 1 atm. The simulation has indicated that DMMP fills the entire available free volume with its density roughly corresponding to the liquid density. The predicted loadings amount to 0.8 g of DMMP/1 g of 1 or 44%. To determine whether all of the DMMP loaded into the host framework can be released before the decomposition of 1, which happens at temperature 100 °C higher than the boiling point (bp) of DMMP, 1·FR was insulated at 195 °C for half an hour and the weight loss was record by TGA at the same time. Nevertheless, the TGA results indicate that the amount of DMMP removed before the thermal decomposition of 1 reaches up to 33% (11% less than the predicted loading). The same amount was observed in the case of the 1·FR sample thermally insulated at 195 °C (15 °C higher than bp of DMMP) until no weight loss could be observed (b). This observable partial irreversible adsorption of DMMP may be assigned to the interactions between the −PO subgroup of DMMP and dehydrated CuII, which comprise an unsaturated open metal site. As shown in photographs within a, after being heated at 300 °C, the residues of 1 and 1·FR show remarkable distinctions. The intumescent residue of 1·FR arises from the reaction of the irreversibly adsorbed DMMP and the framework of 1, which generates phospho-carbonaceous compounds. The irreversible adsorption of DMMP is further confirmed by the elemental distribution scan (EDS) of 1·FR and the residue insulated at 300 °C for half an hour (c). The evenly distributed phosphorus can still be observed after 1·FR was heated at 110 °C higher than the bp of DMMP, which indicates the strong interaction of DMMP with the framework of 1 during the heating process.

elements.content: To confirm the interaction of DMMP with the framework of 1, single-crystal diffraction data of 1·FR was collected (Table S2). The encapsulation of DMMP did not change the space group of the host framework (Fm3̅m). After FR adsorption, each CuII ion adopts a pyramidal coordination geometry, in which the axial coordinative site is partially occupied by the oxygen atom of the phosphonate group in DMMP (), leaving H2O as the rest coordinative occupier. The distance between the CuII and phosphate oxygen atom (2.21(5) Å) suggests a coordinative interaction between the copper dimmer and the DMMP molecule. The occupying ratio (ca. 30%) of DMMP corresponds well with its irreversible adsorption amount calculated from TGA, giving the formula of 1·FR as [Cu3(BTC)2(DMMP)0.91(H2O)2.09]·(DMMP)2.48. Considering the geometry of the cage in 1 and the DMMP structure, we believe that the incomplete occupation of the axial coordinative sites of CuII by DMMP is mainly because of the larger guest molecule size and relatively narrow space around the copper dimmer. Considering the results of single-crystal structure refinement, atomic displacement parameters of terminal carbon atoms in DMMP are larger than tyhose of the same type of atoms in the host framework, which should be caused by the flexibility of DMMP molecules and the intrinsic high symmetry of the host framework so that the electron cloud density of highly disordered methyl and methoxy groups of DMMP is distributed around the phosphorus atom. Despite the latter, considering the well-refined phosphonate oxygen atom, the coordination between DMMP and 1 is reliably proved. According to the analysis above, 1·FR can be considered as a hierarchically functionalized MOF because of the simultaneous existence of open metal site coordination and pore capsulation within DMMP and 1, which can possibly improve both flame retardancy and mechanical properties of the UP composites in different ways.

elements.content: As shown in Table S3, composites with different ratios of components have been prepared, including 1·FR x /UP and 1 x /UP (x = 10 or 19, representing the corresponding additive percentage, Table S3). PXRD patterns indicate that the structure of 1 maintains well after being embedded into UP, even after months (Figure S1). At the same time, the composites prepared by physical blend of DMMP, activated 1, and UP (FR 0.41x /1 0.59x /UP) are also made for the comparison with 1·FR x /UP. With the same formulation but different interaction between DMMP and 1, the effectivity of our hierarchical functionalization strategy could be illustrated in the fire behavior and mechanical characterizations.
elements.clean_text:
Processability of UP Composites

As shown in Table S3, composites with different ratios of components have been prepared, including 1⋅FR  x /UP and 1  x /UP (x = 10 or 19, representing the corresponding additive percentage, Table S3). PXRD patterns indicate that the structure of 1 maintains well after being embedded into UP, even after months (Figure S1). At the same time, the composites prepared by physical blend of DMMP, activated 1, and UP (FR 0.41x /1 0.59x /UP) are also made for the comparison with 1⋅FR  x /UP. With the same formulation but different interaction between DMMP and 1, the effectivity of our hierarchical functionalization strategy could be illustrated in the fire behavior and mechanical characterizations.

elements.content: We compared the processabilities of 1, 1·FR, and the traditional FR, that is, DMMP, under the same dosage. With the curing reagent recommended by the manufacturer of the UP resin, 1·FR x /UP can be well cured, that is, the specimen shows a smooth surface, with no bubble release observed and with a negligible odor of VOC composing the resin. The good compactness and distribution of 1·FR in the composite can be observed in scanning electron microscopy (SEM, a and S2a,b) images. In contrast, 1 x /UP and FR 0.41x /1 0.59x /UP show more bubbles inside the cured specimen (b,c and S2c,d), which should arise from the gas released from the guest-free 1 during the exothermic curing process. On the other hand, at 10 wt % DMMP dosage, an undercured specimen was obtained. Even with a much lengthened curing time, the specimen can still bend and exhibit a very sticky surface as well as a strong odor of styrene (one of the main volatile components of the UP resin). With 19 wt % of DMMP, the specimen is fully liquidized because of the plasticization effect of DMMP. These observations indicate the superiority in processability of 1·FR x /UP, whereas the guest-free 1 and DMMP exhibit an opposite trend as additives for UP.

elements.content: All of the composites exhibit one-step decompositions, which start at different temperatures depending on the composition (Figure S3, Table S4). Compared with neat UP, thermal decomposition of all of the additive-modified composites is brought forward to different extents. Among all of the composites, 1·FR 19/UP has the highest thermal stability, whereas 1 19/UP shows the lowest initial decomposition temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Fire Behaviors of UP Composites

All of the composites exhibit one-step decompositions, which start at different temperatures depending on the composition (Figure S3, Table S4). Compared with neat UP, thermal decomposition of all of the additive-modified composites is brought forward to different extents. Among all of the composites, 1⋅FR 19/UP has the highest thermal stability, whereas 1 19/UP shows the lowest initial decomposition temperature.

elements.content: A similar trend is seen in the limiting oxygen index (LOI), which reflects the minimum oxygen content sustaining the burning of samples (a). The addition of 1 remarkably reduces the LOI from 20.5 (for neat UP) to 20.0 (for 1 10/UP) and 19.4 (for 1 19/UP). The earlier decomposition of the composites can be explained by the CuII ions, which accelerated the decomposition of molecular chains of the polymer because of the catalytic interaction of OMS and unsaturated covalent bonds in the UP matrix. After being further functionalized by DMMP, 1·FR influenced the LOI of composites in quite an opposite way. 1·FR 10/UP and 1·FR 19/UP exhibit increased LOI values up to 22.5 and 24.4, respectively. These results imply the synergetic flame-retardant effect between 1 and DMMP. To prove this assumption, more tests are further carried out. Table S5 demonstrates that a single addition of DMMP improves the LOI of UP. On the other hand, the physically blended composite FR 7.8/1 11.2/UP does not exhibit the LOI value in between the ones of FR 7.8/UP and 1 11.2/UP but rather exhibits a greater improvement, which proves the synergetic effect of DMMP and 1. Additionally, the higher LOI of 1·FR 19/UP than FR 7.8/1 11.2/UP should be attributed to the different interactions between CuII atoms and their surrounding molecules. Considering that there are still large amounts of copper ions in the composites, the acceleration of polymer decomposition caused by OMS should be restrained by the coordination between phosphonate groups and unsaturated CuII dimmers ().

elements.content: To monitor the fire behaviors in detail, the cone calorimeter test was also carried out (b,c and S4–S8, and S6), in which the properties of heat release and smoke produce were characterized. By adding 1 and 1·FR, although the time to ignition (TTI) of composites is shortened, the peak of heat release rate (pHRR) and total heat release (THR) decreased in varying degrees compared with neat UP (), meaning that the heat release during combustion is reduced. As shown in b, 1·FR produces a much lower THR and a longer TTI than 1. Both 1·FR 10/UP and 1·FR 19/UP similarly reduce the THR by ca. 45% with respect to UP (). Different from THR, the pHRR showed a strong relevance to the formulation of composites. In 1·FR 19/UP, an obvious platform is observed in the HRR curve, and the pHRR reduced by 72% compared with neat UP and 40% compared with 1·FR 10/UP. However, for 1 x /UP, the pHRR reduced by no more than 17%. Although many traditional phosphorous-containing FRs work effectively in reducing the THR and HRR, the high CO and smoke release may constitute a fatal disadvantage in real applications. According to the total smoke produced (TSP) curves, the guest-free 1 does not help in smoke suppression. 1·FR 10/UP shows good performance in smoke suppression (lowest TSP among all samples in our work), and COPmax and SPRmax of 1·FR 19/UP are lower than those of UP and all of the other samples simultaneously containing DMMP and 1 (Figures S6–S8, Table S6). These results suggest that 1·FR has some effects on smoke suppression and toxicity reduction. It is worth pointing out that the physical-blend-prepared samples FR 0.41x /1 0.59x /UP present similar results of HRR and THR, which should be the result of the synergetic effects of MOF and DMMP. However, they show worse performances in smoke and CO suppression and shorter TTI than 1·FR x /UP at the same formulation. This should be explained by the same reason of the similar trend observed in the LOI test (Figures S4–S8, Table S6). The acceleration of polymer decomposition by OMS and the synergetic flame-retardant effect of DMMP and 1 both contribute to the result.
elements.clean_text: To monitor the fire behaviors in detail, the cone calorimeter test was also carried out (b,c and S4-S8,  and S6), in which the properties of heat release and smoke produce were characterized. By adding 1 and 1⋅FR, although the time to ignition (TTI) of composites is shortened, the peak of heat release rate (pHRR) and total heat release (THR) decreased in varying degrees compared with neat UP (), meaning that the heat release during combustion is reduced. As shown in b, 1⋅FR produces a much lower THR and a longer TTI than 1. Both 1⋅FR 10/UP and 1⋅FR 19/UP similarly reduce the THR by ca. 45% with respect to UP (). Different from THR, the pHRR showed a strong relevance to the formulation of composites. In 1⋅FR 19/UP, an obvious platform is observed in the HRR curve, and the pHRR reduced by 72% compared with neat UP and 40% compared with 1⋅FR 10/UP. However, for 1  x /UP, the pHRR reduced by no more than 17%. Although many traditional phosphorous-containing FRs work effectively in reducing the THR and HRR, the high CO and smoke release may constitute a fatal disadvantage in real applications. According to the total smoke produced (TSP) curves, the guest-free 1 does not help in smoke suppression. 1⋅FR 10/UP shows good performance in smoke suppression (lowest TSP among all samples in our work), and COPmax and SPRmax of 1⋅FR 19/UP are lower than those of UP and all of the other samples simultaneously containing DMMP and 1 (Figures S6-S8, Table S6). These results suggest that 1⋅FR has some effects on smoke suppression and toxicity reduction. It is worth pointing out that the physical-blend-prepared samples FR 0.41x /1 0.59x /UP present similar results of HRR and THR, which should be the result of the synergetic effects of MOF and DMMP. However, they show worse performances in smoke and CO suppression and shorter TTI than 1⋅FR  x /UP at the same formulation. This should be explained by the same reason of the similar trend observed in the LOI test (Figures S4-S8, Table S6). The acceleration of polymer decomposition by OMS and the synergetic flame-retardant effect of DMMP and 1 both contribute to the result.

The results of TGA, LOI, and remarkably shortened TTI all suggest that the decomposition of molecular chains in 1 x /UP is significantly accelerated, which can be ascribed to coordination-unsaturated CuII ions in 1. They catalyzed the decomposing reactions of unsaturated covalent bonds in the UP matrix. The effective heat of combustion (EHC) reflects the extent of complete combustion taking place during the measurement of cone calorimetry. The very close EHC values of 1 x /UP and UP suggest that no more incomplete combustion of 1 x /UP happens in the gaseous phase compared with UP. In other words, the main flame-retardant mechanism of 1 should be attributed to the condensed phase mechanism, in which the char residue formed serves as an insulation layer hindering the heat release during the combustion. Although no remarkable distinction can be observed in the morphology of the char residue (Figure S9), the Raman spectra show that the signal of the G-band (diffusion band around 1580 cm–1) corresponding to the C–C vibrations in aromatic structures and the D-band (diffusion band around 1350 cm–1) related to sp3 hybridized C atoms can be clearly identified in all of the residue samples. Among all of the composites, 1·FR 19/UP has the highest peak intensity ratio of D-band/G-band (I D/I G), meaning that more turbostratic carbon structures growing among polyaromatic layers are formed during the combustion, producing a stronger char layer, which plays important roles in the fire-resistance process. Nevertheless, the char layer formed in 1 x /UP is not strong enough to prevent the dispersion of soot particles so that the corresponding SPR and TSP values remain high. From the lowered EHC and high amount of char residue, the mechanisms of both gaseous and condensed phases in 1·FR x /UP are suggested. The radical capture from the gaseous phase should be attributed to the phosphorus-containing DMMP in 1·FR, which is also reflected in the higher CO produced. The polyphosphoric acid and phospho-carbonaceous layer formed during the combustion further help in the reduction of THR and HRR and in smoke suppression (Figure S9). It should be noted that, under the same additive ratio, 1·FR x /UP exhibits char residue amount very close to that of 1 x /UP, although the content of 1 is only 59% of that in 1 x /UP, meaning that the DMMP has non-negligible contributions to the condensed phase formation during the combustion. As reported in many previous cases, DMMP mainly worked as a gaseous phase flame retardant. Therefore, we can conclude that through the interaction with MOF, the flame-retardant mechanism of DMMP has been regulated in both ways, which is apparently more effective in fire resistance. Considering that there is still a large amount of copper ions in 1·FR x /UP, the acceleration of polymer decomposition caused by OMS should be restrained by the coordination between phosphonate groups and unsaturated CuII dimmers (). In other words, the hierarchical functionalization presented in this work not only overcomes the negative effects to the thermal stability of the polymer matrix but also gives rise to a stronger synergetic flame-retardant effect between 1 and DMMP.

elements.content: To further compare the influence of the additives on the mechanical properties of UP composites, the tensile and impact tests and dynamical mechanical analysis (DMA) were conducted (, ). As shown in Table S7, guest-free 1 increased storage modulus E′ modestly possibly because of the rigidity. Nevertheless, the two peaks in the loss factor curve imply that there could be more than one glass-transition temperature (T g) in 1 x /UP composites (Figure S11), suggesting that the composites may not undergo a curation homogeneously, which restricts the real utility of composites. This should be attributed to the large amount of active CuII ions contained in the composite. In many cases, low amount of Cu salts or complexes acts as promoters in the curing reactions of UP, whereas the excess dosage will cause the explosive polymerization and the permanent undercure of polymers. At the same time, the possibility that some short branches of molecular chains in UP might insert into pores on the surface of 1 cannot be excluded. Together with those bubbles produced during the curing process (Figure S2c), all of these factors exacerbate the inhomogeneity of composites. As a result, there were fierce deteriorations of tensile strength (σ) (42% decreased), ε (57% reduced), and E frac (47% lowered) at high dosage of 1 (1 19/UP, , Table S3).
elements.clean_text:
Mechanical Properties

To further compare the influence of the additives on the mechanical properties of UP composites, the tensile and impact tests and dynamical mechanical analysis (DMA) were conducted (, ). As shown in Table S7, guest-free 1 increased storage modulus E' modestly possibly because of the rigidity. Nevertheless, the two peaks in the loss factor curve imply that there could be more than one glass-transition temperature (T g) in 1  x /UP composites (Figure S11), suggesting that the composites may not undergo a curation homogeneously, which restricts the real utility of composites. This should be attributed to the large amount of active CuII ions contained in the composite. In many cases, low amount of Cu salts or complexes acts as promoters in the curing reactions of UP, whereas the excess dosage will cause the explosive polymerization and the permanent undercure of polymers. At the same time, the possibility that some short branches of molecular chains in UP might insert into pores on the surface of 1 cannot be excluded. Together with those bubbles produced during the curing process (Figure S2c), all of these factors exacerbate the inhomogeneity of composites. As a result, there were fierce deteriorations of tensile strength (σ) (42% decreased), ε (57% reduced), and E frac (47% lowered) at high dosage of 1 (1 19/UP, , Table S3).

As expected, when the activity of CuII ions was restrained through being saturated by DMMP, the negative impact toward the polymerization can be diminished. Apart from that, both the organic ligand in 1 and hydrocarbon groups of DMMP molecules exposed on the outer surface of HKUST-1 endow the 1·FR particles with stronger interfacial interactions with the polymer matrix in comparison with guest-free 1, which brings about a good affinity of 1·FR with the UP matrix. Therefore, the movement of polymer molecular chains is restricted in 1·FR x /UP, which is reflected by increased T g (more than 12 °C, Figure S11, Table S7). On the other hand, in 1·FR 10/UP and 1·FR 19/UP, the σ increased by 58 and 53% and ε showed simultaneous increases of 43 and 83%, respectively (, and S7). Additionally, at high dosage, no deterioration of impact strength (E frac) can be observed (5.0 kJ/m2 for 1·FR 19/UP and 4.9 kJ/m2 for UP), implying that 1·FR might be a load-bearing component in the UP matrix. The significantly increased T g and tensile strength imply the elimination of the plasticization effect of DMMP, which should be attributed to the encapsulation by MOF. Together with the rigidity and polymer affinity of the 1·FR, improved performances in tensile and impact tests were obtained in 1·FR x /UP. All of the results mentioned above indicate that our hierarchical functionalization strategy works effectively not only in improving the fire safety but also in ameliorating mechanical properties of polymer composites ().

Therefore, the movement of polymer molecular chains is restricted in 1⋅FR  x /UP, which is reflected by increased T g (more than 12 °C, Figure S11, Table S7). elements.content: The mechanical properties of FR 0.41x /1 0.59x /UP are affected by the promoter effect of OMS in 1, bubbles produced during the curing process, and the plasticization effect of DMMP simultaneously. The corresponding σ, ε, and E frac finally turned out to be in the middle of 1·FR x /UP and 1 x /UP. These results are in agreement with those of DMA (Table S7, Figure S11).

The corresponding σ, ε, and E frac finally turned out to be in the middle of 1⋅FR  x /UP and 1  x /UP. These results are in agreement with those of DMA (Table S7, Figure S11).

elements.content: In conclusion, we have presented a hierarchical strategy to improve mechanical and fire safety of composite materials by incorporation of guest-molecule-loaded MOF particles. In this work, a modern, phosphorous-based flame-retardant DMMP and an environmentally friendly MOF HKUST-1 with open metal sites were employed to assemble a polymer additive 1·FR, with which polymer composites with remarkably improved processability have been prepared. This hierarchical strategy and the selection of components allowed not only the flame-retardant mechanism of the composite to be regulated but also the affinity of the additive to the polymer matrix to be strengthened, resulting in more effective flame retardancy and mechanical reinforcement of the composite. The presented hierarchical strategy for developing high-performance composite materials by incorporating MOF particles loaded with property-enhancing molecules can be adopted to other applications by selection of polymer-compatible MOFs as well as property-barring MOF–guest composites.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have presented a hierarchical strategy to improve mechanical and fire safety of composite materials by incorporation of guest-molecule-loaded MOF particles. In this work, a modern, phosphorous-based flame-retardant DMMP and an environmentally friendly MOF HKUST-1 with open metal sites were employed to assemble a polymer additive 1⋅FR, with which polymer composites with remarkably improved processability have been prepared. This hierarchical strategy and the selection of components allowed not only the flame-retardant mechanism of the composite to be regulated but also the affinity of the additive to the polymer matrix to be strengthened, resulting in more effective flame retardancy and mechanical reinforcement of the composite. The presented hierarchical strategy for developing high-performance composite materials by incorporating MOF particles loaded with property-enhancing molecules can be adopted to other applications by selection of polymer-compatible MOFs as well as property-barring MOF-guest composites.

elements.content: Unsaturated polyester (UP, NORSODYNE H 15239 TAE) was supplied by Polynt S.A., Spain, with density 1.09 g·cm–3. Commercialized Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), methanol, N,N′-dimethylformamide, and dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP) were used directly without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Sample Preparation Methods

Materials

Unsaturated polyester (UP, NORSODYNE H 15239 TAE) was supplied by Polynt S.A., Spain, with density 1.09 g⋅cm-3. Commercialized Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), methanol, N,N'-dimethylformamide, and dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP) were used directly without further purification.

elements.content: The microcrystal sample was synthesized according to the method reported before. Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (10.5 g), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (5.5 g), methanol (60.0 mL), and N,N′-dimethylformamide (60.0 mL) were stirred well in a 200.0 mL Teflon-lined solvothermal reactor with a stainless steel shell and heated at 120 °C for 30 h. Blue crystallites were collected as precipitate and washed with methanol 2–3 times.
elements.clean_text:
Sample Preparation

Synthesis of HKUST-1 (1⋅Guest, [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3]⋅Guest)

The microcrystal sample was synthesized according to the method reported before. Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (10.5 g), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (5.5 g), methanol (60.0 mL), and N,N'-dimethylformamide (60.0 mL) were stirred well in a 200.0 mL Teflon-lined solvothermal reactor with a stainless steel shell and heated at 120 °C for 30 h. Blue crystallites were collected as precipitate and washed with methanol 2-3 times.

elements.content:
The as-synthesized 1·g was heated under vacuum at 170 °C for 5 h to remove all of the guest molecules in the pore system.

Preparation of FR-Loaded MOF Powder <bold>1</bold>·<bold>FR</bold> ([Cu<sub>3</sub>(BTC)<sub>2</sub>(DMMP)<sub>0.91</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2.09</sub>]·(DMMP)<sub>2.48</sub>)

The powder of 1 was dipped into DMMP for 3 days to make sure that the maximum amount of DMMP is loaded into the pore system of HKUST-1. Afterward, the powder was washed with acetone quickly to remove all of the FR adhering on the particle surface and dried at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Activated MOF 1 

The as-synthesized 1⋅g was heated under vacuum at 170 °C for 5 h to remove all of the guest molecules in the pore system.

Preparation of FR-Loaded MOF Powder 1⋅FR ([Cu3(BTC)2(DMMP)0.91(H2O)2.09]⋅(DMMP)2.48)

The powder of 1 was dipped into DMMP for 3 days to make sure that the maximum amount of DMMP is loaded into the pore system of HKUST-1. Afterward, the powder was washed with acetone quickly to remove all of the FR adhering on the particle surface and dried at room temperature.

elements.content: First, the solid filler 1·FR (15.00 or 28.50 g) was mixed with the UP resin (132.0 or 118.5 g) by means of a triple-roll mix (EXAKT 80E) for 0.5 h. The mixture was transferred onto a magnetic stirring apparatus, and the curing agent POLYCAT34 (3.0 g) was blended into the mixture and then stirred until a homogenous suspension was obtained. The suspension was cast into the poly­(tetrafluoroethylene) molds immediately. The cure process was carried out at room temperature for 24 h.
elements.clean_text:
UP Composites with FR-Loaded MOF as Additives 1⋅FR  x /UP (x = 10 or 19)

First, the solid filler 1⋅FR (15.00 or 28.50 g) was mixed with the UP resin (132.0 or 118.5 g) by means of a triple-roll mix (EXAKT 80E) for 0.5 h. The mixture was transferred onto a magnetic stirring apparatus, and the curing agent POLYCAT34 (3.0 g) was blended into the mixture and then stirred until a homogenous suspension was obtained. The suspension was cast into the poly(tetrafluoroethylene) molds immediately. The cure process was carried out at room temperature for 24 h.
